Play details
The Turke. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1610. Date first performed: 1607-1608. THE TVRKE. A Worthie TRAGEDIE. Scænarum Personæ. Mulleasses the Turke Borgias Gouernour of Florence. Duke of Venice. Duke of Ferrara. Bordello an humerous trauellour. Pantofle his Page Eunuchus seruant to Borgias Lord of Florence. Phego a gentleman vsher. Philenzo a gentleman of Ferrara: Prusias a gentleman of Venice A Fryer Iulia Dutchesse of Florence. Timoclea Borgias wife Amada his daughter Madam Fulsome an old Gentlewoman

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Amada Borgias, Governor of Florence Timoclea, wife of Borgias Bordello Eunuchus Duke of Ferrara Pantofle, Page to Bordello Friar Madam Fulsome Julia, Duchess of Florence Phego Prusias Mulleasses the Turk Philenzo Lord of Florence Prologue/Epilogue Duke ofVenice Combined speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Front matter Sume superbiam quesitam meritis Horat.

sp.l: The marks and notions extant in each spirit,
Sealed by the industrious hand of art and merit,
Methinks appear transparent (as the mind
By sense were bounded and might seem confined
In the external eye) nor shall our tragic muse,
(If strong hope fail not) need a coined excuse
But to those marginal notes of yours do bring
(In following numbers from the learned spring)
Matter instructive to enrich their parts
Where knowledge reigns crowned with it own deserts,
Let such with serious and impartial hearing
Sound sense, quick sight and judgment never erring:
Survey and censure the mineral frame
Of his elaborate work: and if his name
Merit regard, and you vouchsafe to grace him
With eminent love, or amongst those laureates place him,
That with the magic of sweet poesy,
Transfer Pernassus into Brittany,
He shall digest the Chaos of his brain,
To tuneful order and acquire a strain,
Near to the music of the heavenly spheres,
To fit Times guard and ravish choicest ears.

div2.stage: Main text Mulleasses the Turke, Actus primi. Scæna prima. Enter aloft Iulia, and Amada.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How sweet are things known in their contraries
When only apprehension, and sick thoughts
Foster a greedy longing Amada?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Madam you breath: no covetous hand
Takes the air from you: no contrariety
Bandies against your rest: as I am modest,
My fathers seeming harsh ungentleness
Is but a misty policy, to beguile some time.
Then be yourself and jovial:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yet why should I repine,
At this my forced restraint of liberty?
Our life is but a sailing to our death,
Through the worlds Ocean: it makes no matter then
Whether we put into the worlds vast Sea,
Shipped in a Pinasse or an Argosy:

sp.speaker: Amad.
sp.l: No Matter: when we hope for change of vessels Lady
And in that hope beguile your passions:
Give your sight freedom over the city walls
And see what worthy objects meet your eyes:
See where two Dukes, each like a god of war,
Lie both entrenched against the gates of Florence
To gain your love: on the west side, there is
Ferrara hangs his scarlet ensigns forth
And woos in blood: then from the East behold
In a white ensign filled with stars of gold,
Burns the Venetian's love: the morning Sun
Courts not the world more amorously: he as mild
As Mirrhas boy doth prove that loves a child,
Not techy if not wronged. The other like Mars
Hems in his Venus in his arms of steel.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke of Ferrara at one doore and the Duke of Venice at another doore and meete at the midst of the stage.
sp.l: And vows a conquest: Se where they appear:
Madam your love, which hand for a Dukedom?
Were I an Orator I could praise Ferrara,
He like the marble statue of some God,
Carries command in his proportion,
In him love seems a warrior for the fire,
Of best affection burns in hot desire.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And yet methinks the smooth Venetian
Should more content a Venus:
In him love seemeth as he is, calm and mild,
Pleasing and sportful: things rough and violent
Die like abortive fruit before perfection.
They are pursy and short breathed: the ardor of true love
Burns in a calm breast: in him affections
Are not like tempests raging: yet of force
Like an even gale of wind to bear loves ship
Unto the port of happiness: his fire
Burns, and consumes not, but maintain desire.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Give over my claim: that should argue,
A too cold temperature in love: besides
It would disable the Venetian power
Not to make good his challenge: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Why she is mine by promise.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I grant, that Borgias her Uncle and Protector
Promised you that which he cannot perform.
But know Ferrara that my claim takes root
And grows upon the promise of the State,
I by the Senate was assured her love,
And on that ground the justice of my cause
Pleads. Thus in arms against the city walls.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Herein you err: for know the Florentine
Dying a Prince powerful and absolute
(Not countermanded by a popular voice
Or by the ambitious factions of a Senate)
Leaves the Protector in his daughters nonage
Free like himself, and absolute: of power
To promise and perform: on his assurance
Lives my loves right: then were you both
Direct opposers of what I claim, by heaven
And by that influence that made me great
I would pursue my challenge through your bloods.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: Give not such passage to your heat my Lord

sp.speaker: Ferr:
sp.l: Then give my power a passage to my Love:

sp.speaker: Ven:
sp.l: That I demand of you.

sp.speaker: Ferr:
sp.l: And I command:
That without stay you raise your powers
And leave this cities siege unto our arms,
Or what we aimed at them we will turn on you.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Although your power we are equal with your pride
I would dare stay Ferrara, and proclaim
Thy title weak, thy claim litigious:
Mine only just, apparent, righteous.
Yet let not fury so impeach our wisdoms
To jar for her another doth possess,
And make our follies laughter to our foes:
Will then Ferrara make his passions subject
To an indifference that I shall propound?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: If the indifference you shall propound
Divides not me from Iulia:

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: She is the maine claim of both our armed loves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And with out her there is no indifference.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You are frivolous:
Why know Ferrara, thy prerogative
Extends no further than thy sword can reach:
Then when thy conquests hath confirmed thy will
Thou mayst capitulate with rude commands,
Till when proud Prince, stoop at imperious chance:
For did no other title than my sword
Make my claim righteous: yet the doubtful lot
Cast on the ends of war, carries my fate
Even with thy pride: the Lady as mine own
To show an eminence that over looks thy hope,
I challenge and aver the right of war
Due to my sword.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Unsheathe it then.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Yes at thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What means this sudden parley from the walls?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What are the Dukes at odds?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hark Madam from the walls---
A sudden parley speaks unto the Dukes

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Was that that staid their swords.

sp.speaker: Amad.
sp.l: I would fain have seen,
how like Esops warrior they could have fought,
For that a third carries away.
Some new devise of policy hath caused
This unexpected change: not long since
It was resolved in council to maintain
The siege against the hottest opposition.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Did I not think my fortunes ebb at lowest?
It might amaze me.

sp.speaker: Amad.
sp.l: My liberty
May soon give notice to you: then let us away:
A Sun may rise to make it a happy day.

div2.stage: Enter aloft Borgias and the Senate.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: To whom speaks Borgias?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Dukes to you both.
The present and unlooked for cause of grief,
That now hath took possession on our breasts,
Cuts of the feeling of all outward fear:
Our private griefs were desperate: did there not
A public care of others burden us
We think you wronged, I and the Senate hear,
Causes of both the nonsuits of your loves,
Appeal unto remission.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But whether bends your far-fetched Oratory?
Restore the Lady unto me: and on my honours pawn
I will free your City from the arms of Venice.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Senate, and you on whose authority,
And pawn of honour I engaged my love,
Slaved my affections, and did prostitute
The freedom of my soul to Iulia:
Sleight not your wisdoms and your worths in counsel,
To serve the ends of hidden policy:
Make good your words engaged, and as I live
A Prince unstained in honour, I will free
Your City from Ferraras hottest fury.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Alas my gracious and renowned Lords,
I grieve to see your passions,
Emptied of the objects that they wrought upon:
I am the Ambassador of heavy news,
To you I am sure as heavy as to us.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Speak it.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: O it doth press the Organs of my speech,
And like a lethargy doth numb those motions
should give it utterance.

sp.speaker: Ferra.
sp.l: Hold the Protector there from falling.
Some standers-by help to unlade his burthen.
The Camel else will sink down under it.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Scoff not my gracious Prince: the grief I see
Will be as heavy on thy now light head,
As it is on mine: the Lady whom you loue---

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Why what of her?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Where is she? speak:

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Singing with Angels in the quire of heaven,
The Requiem of Saints.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: She is dead!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She is dead!

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Aye Lords unto your loves.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: O my Loves hard fate.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: And now my Lords, seeing that she is dead,
For whom you raised these arms against our walls,
I hope your furious angers live no longer.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: We are appeased: Uenice I thus salute thee,
and reconcile my fury in thy arms.
'sdeath dead?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Descend Protector, with her our arms are dead.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: I am amazed: possess me patience,
Credulity Ferrara is a virtue,
I believe it: Borgias: o my spleen,
That he should think me so ridiculous,
To fasten any faith on policy,
The stateliest general prop is jealousy,
On all men and their actions: I know it not.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Should I think her murdered, or that she still doth live?
And feed some hope by deeming him a villain,
That sooths this sorrowful news into our ears?
I might herein seem politic, and nurse
Some mischief in my bosom for revenge,
Of that wherein I but suspect a wrong.
The tricks of State-moles that work under Princes,
Are at the best, but like the vipers young,
That howsoever prodigious and hurtful,
To many open and secure passengers,
Yet do they never live: without the death
Of him that first gave motion to their breath.
This keeps me honest still, the heavens and fate
Are the best guardians to a wronged state.

div2.stage: A short flourish. Enter Borgias and the Senate.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Laying aside all fear of what you may,
Thus to your powers we do expose our lives,
Your wrongs we do confess might speak revenge,
Did not this flood of sudden grief, take up
All passion in itself: speak mighty Dukes,
Lives Florence in your loves? With Iulias death
Dies the memorial of your former wrongs?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I forget them all.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: I take no pleasure in revenge.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Then are our City gates ope to your loves,
And beg a favour due unto the dead:
This night the funeral hearse of Iulia,
(I know that name is dear unto you both)
Returns again to her creation.
This night the ravenous mother of the world,
(The all corrupting earth that eats her young)
Swalloweth the body of your Iulia.
This night she takes a farewell of us all:
Then let it be a witness of your loves,
To give her hearse an honour with your presence.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Should we not grant this, we might be taxed
Of much dishonour.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: I were not worthy that it should be said
I levied arms for love of Iulia,
Should I deny my presence at her hearse.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: My love, the near alliance to her blood,
The dear remembrance of my Sovereign dead,
Whose love committed her unto my care,
Makes me accept this honour done to me:
And I stand bound in bonds of gratitude
To both your princely worths: in lieu of which,
Let my emboldened weakness mighty Lords,
Presume to invite you to a funeral supper,
A banquet forced by ceremonious custom,
As a due obsequy.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The love of Iulia
Exacts from me all rights of custom.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: I yield my presence.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Your guards shall be my honour for this night,
Your several armies during your stay in Florence,
Shall be maintained at our Cities charge,
In recompense of love to Iulia.

sp.speaker: Ten.
sp.l: We thank you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We thank yous

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Nor give we expectation of proud pomp,
Of shows, or Pageants, for your entertainment:
Our bells ring forth our sorrows in sad peals,
No pleasant changes to give Princes welcome,
Our Churches stand not garnished with pictures,
To please devoted superstition with,
But mourn in black. Our Church men
Leave their chanting Anthems, and their daily Mass,
To sing continual requiems to her soul.
Sorrow sits sad and weeping in our streets,
All eyes are wet with tears, save those where grief
Hath dried all moisture up. Our sucking infants
Are pale and lean with hanging on the breasts,
Of grief-spent mothers: If these may welcome you,
We will give you prodigal welcome to our City.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Such welcome fits the death of Iulia.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: So should all mourn and weep for Iulia.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: So do we mourn and weep for Iulia.
Lead on unto the City: how slow paced is sorrow?
Grief is a Tortoise to the nimble sense,
And chills their motions, the officers of love,
Live at our funeral, and in death do move.

div2.stage: Scæna secunda. Enter Amada and Eunuchus.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Eunuchus?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: What solemnity is that the City celebrates?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: The Dukes of Venice and Ferrara,
Are with your father entered the walls
Unto the funerals of Iulia.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Why, is Iulia dead?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: I hope your Ladiship---

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy: the remembrance of her
Makes me still think she lives.
And that is the cause they parleyed on the walls.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: True Madam.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Remove a while.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: At your service Lady.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Iulia given out for dead,
And live in durance at my fathers will?
It is strange: the Dukes invited to her funeral.
More mists of policy? O simplicity!
The clue of reason cannot guide the fate,
Of this Dedalion maze: were it not profane
In me to question nature for my birth,
And quarrel with my stars for being daughter
To him whom I suspect to be a villain:
Some inspiration of religious thoughts,
Make nature less in me, and bear my duty
Even with his awe whose uncontrolled command,
Frees our obedience from our impious parents.
My father Borgias left in charge with me,
That I should keep fair Iulia: I am her Jailer,
To whom, both he and I do owe allegiance.
Distracted duty, how should I bestow thee?
On the right owner, Justice I adore thee.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Amada.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: My love and duty.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Alone?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: My mothers Eunuch:

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: How fares Iulia?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Lives as you commanded, unseen and private.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Thy mothers dead.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Defend it heavens!

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Dead: no more: Eunuchus?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: My love and service.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: You gave it out last night as I commanded
Timoclea my wife was sick.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: I did if it like your grace.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: When sets the Sun?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: Some six hours hence.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Tonight will be too soon: tomorrow morning
Rumour it about the City, my wife is dead,
Say abroad she is dead.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: So shall thy duty keep me bound to thee.
Amada: some thing more I have to say,
Prepare for marriage.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: For marriage?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Question me not, thou must be married,
Mulleassesis thy husband, my word hath sealed it,
Be still my Argues, and keep Iulia.
Death to my soul! Eunuchus
Canst thou unknown (to any save thy self)
Poison a groom to stuff a coffin with?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: I can to please your Lordship:

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: O thou shalt please us highly! I have great use
Of such a thing, I prithee do it:
My wife last night was poisoned, her body
The world believes is Iulias, supposed dead.
Now for the second funeral of my wife.
Her coffin must be filled up with some slave,
He shall be honoured princely to his grave.
The funeral stays my presence: Amada
See to my Iulia, if Mulleasses move,
Be kind and gentle to his proffered love.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Here is a distracted labyrinth of wit,
Iulia alive, and yet her funeral kept:
My mother dead and never Sick: it is true:
To many, death is sudden and unlooked for:
So it was to her: and in the midst of death,
I must be married: death take me too,
Let me not live to see those tapers burn,
That lead me to his bed: where is sanctity?
Religion is the fools bridle, worn by policy:
As horse wear trappers to seem fair in show,
And make the worlds eye dote on what we seem.
Be silent yet for duty stops thy mouth,
I will in to Iulia, it is she and I,
That must be Chorus in this Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: Howsoever my fortunes make me now a slave
I was a free born Christians son in Cyprus,
When Famagusta by the Turke was sacked:
In the division of which City spoils,
My fortunes fell to Mulleasses lot:
Nor was it Tyranny enough that I was Captive,
My parents robbed of me, and I of them,
But they wronged nature in me, made me an Eunuch,
Disabled of those masculine functions,
Due from our sex: and thus subjected,
These sixteen years unto the vile command,
Of an imperious Turke, I now am given
To serve the hidden secrets of his lust,
Unto Timoclea, the wife of Borgias,
Whose private mixtures I am guilty of:
Betwixt these three I stand as in a maze,
Engaged to all their sins, and made a bawd
To lust and murder: Mulleasses first
Gives me unto Timoclea, that without suspect
I might procure their loves security;
For which they promise me my liberty.
But Borgias whether jealous of his wife,
Or reaching at some further policy,
Binds me with golden offers to his trust,
And first commands me rumour it abroad
Timoclea his wife was sick, when at that instant
She was in health and dancing with her Turke.
Now I must second that report with death,
And say abroad Timoclea is dead:
Short warning for a journey unto heaven:
But (which amazeth most) I must provide
The body of some groom to stop a coffin with.
This is a riddle of some Sphinx, let Oedipus
Unfold the meaning: I leave it to the event,
And think most safety in not knowing it.
I must provide some groom, that is my command.
Prosper me Saturne, and those stars of sin,
Whose influence makes villains fortunate
He kills by law that kills men for a state.
sp.stage: Enter Bordello and Pantofle his Page.
sp.l: But who comes here? o my spruce he---letcher
That makes his boy save him the charges of a bawdy house,
Fore Mahomet an excellent fellow for my Lords coffin:
Assist me power of wit.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.l: Pantofle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: At your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Thou hast been at my pleasure indeed Pantofle, I will retreat into the country, hate this amorous, Court and betake myself to obscurity; I tell thee boy I will return by this Circyan Isle without transformation since Hebe hath discovered her secrets I will turn Iupiter, hate the whole sex of women, and only embrace thee my Ganimede.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'sfoot sir you are as passionate for the disloyalty of your Sempsters as some needy knight would be for the loss of some rich magnificos widow: do you not see how the supporters of the Court, the Lady of the lobby gape after your good parts like so many grigs after fresh water, and can you withhold the dew of your moister element?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I tell thee should the Lady Iulia when she was alive have proffered me her cheek to kiss, I would not have bowed to that painted image for her whole Dukedom: Mercury had no good aspect in the horoscope of my nativity: women and lotium are reciprocal, their savour is noisome.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Why here is a slave in folio will seem to 'slight the love of a Princess, when he would willingly spend his talent on an oyster wise.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Sirrah Pantofle truss up my wardrobe: but withal publish my departure, I would willingly put my creditors to the charge of guarding me out of town.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: It will much scandalise your reputation for to depart indebted: you will be cursed heavily.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: To depart indebted boy, is the only way to be prayed for, seeing they know it is my prosperity and welfare that must make them satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Before heaven an excellent reason.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Pray Sir make even with your Taylor, he is poor.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Most willingly, for I am not possessed of a pannikin, and if he be not before with me, I take it we are even, and may walk in campagne. Pantofle vanish.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I go Sir.

sp.speaker: Eunc.
sp.p: I have it, thanks sweet Thalia, thou hast begot a child of mirth in my brain, I will put it to this creature of Florence to nurse: Saucy Seignior.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Eunuchus, Venus restore thee to thy generation: what doings are now in your quarters?

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Doings: in faith courtly and weak: Cupid help the poor Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: you are above me, I mean not their ingenys or upper galleries:

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Nor I neither: and yet I speak of their understandings, which by reason of a general spring, halt and debility in their hams (heavens know) are most falteringly feeble: but to present the message I am sent for: to your worthiest self, from my Lady and mistress the protectors wife: you are intelligent?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: The beauteous Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Heavens grant she may have the virtue of attraction: for she hath laid open, the luster of her best parts to your grace Sir: nay make not retreat Sir: she knows you disdain her love.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: The truth is I am earthly, and like not to participate with the element of the fire: good Eunuchus commend me to your Lady, and tell her by importuning my affection, she seeks the fall of an innocent.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: True Sir, but with a firm belief of your rising again.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I see no hope of it.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: The harder is her fortune: but hear me, methinks reward should prick you on with more courage, to such an honourable encounter.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Faith Eunuche I have made a vow not to uncase myself to any of that sex.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: It may be you grounded your oath upon the uncleanness of your shirt.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p:
Verily since the relapse of my Sempsters, I have not
addicted myself to that neat and cleanly carriage.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: 'sfoot I thought some foul cause or other, interposed itself betwixt you and my Lady: But sir, I will see all wants supplied, thy debts satisfied, thy fortunes eternally mounted: only be tractable to my poor love-sick Lady and mistress, just and loving.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: As I am, so fates assist me: and Eunuchus here is my hand thou shalt have ample share in my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: By this hand sir but I will not: do not fail sir at eight of the clock to meet me here, where I will deliver you the key of my Ladies chamber: with further instructions in the business, and with assuredness of preferment and promotion.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Dear Eunuch let me hug thee: how I long to manifest thy service to my Lady Timoclea.
sp.l: You will meet?

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: My hand and promise for it.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.l: It shall suffice.
By women man first fell, by them I will rise.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: Ha ha ha: Protector, here is a slave
Shall stuff thy coffin: him thou shalt sacrifice
Unto Timocleas ghost, whose humorous soul
Shall in his passage over Acheron
Make Charon laugh, and the stern judge of hell
Smile at his folly: this is the fatal key
Conducts him to those shades by Borgias hand.
Thus fools must fall, that wise men firm may stand.

div2.stage: Scæna. 3. Enter a Frier, after him a funerall in white, and bearers in white, after them Borgias; then the two Dukes, after them the Senate. etc. A solemne march.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Set down that heavy load of misery,
O would the easing you, might ease my heart!
Pure virgin Hark: O let it not impeach
The gravity of age to let some tears
Fall at thy funeral: true relic of that love
I did inherit from thy fathers mouth,
When to my charge he left his heir and Dukedom
In thee I am deprived of all that honour
I should have purchased by that thankful care
Was due unto thy fathers memory:
Did not my grief load all my powers of speech,
O I could spend my age in commenting
Of those true virtues died with him and thee,
But sorrow shuts my breast: Friar, thine office.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: By that great power is given to me
The gates of heaven I ope to thee,
When amongst the Angels thou shalt sing
The song of Saints before a King,
That sits for ever on his throne,
And giveth light to everyone:
To him thy soul we do bequeath,
Thy body to the earth beneath:
And so we close thy tomb again,
And pray thy soul be free from pain.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: Look from thy holy mansion sacred maid
And see how prostrate I adore thy bliss:
These arms in hope of conquest of thy love
That rolled themselves in steel, shall clasp the air,
And in their empty foldings live still barren
Of all the comfort my youths hope did promise.
And since thy death takes my loves joy from me,
I will die a virgin-Saint and live with thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot vent my breast in love sick terms,
Nor call to record all the gods of love
For my integrity: nor prostitute,
An oily passion curiously composed
Of riming numbers at my mistress hearse:
Or tell her dead trunk my true love in verse:
But since by death her love I am denied,
To say I loud her is Ferraraes pride.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: My honour, and that weak ability
Our state affords, to do your graces service,
Lies at your princely feet, for this your love
Done to the dead: now is Iulia shut
For ever from your eyes: save that she lives
Like a pure relic of some holy Saint,
Shrined in our breasts for ever: let me now renew
My first request, to sup with us tonight,
A ceremony due at funerals.
So shall you double honour unto me,
In doing double honour unto her.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I will do all honour both to her and you.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: I will break no custom.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I humbly thank your graces, please you lead?
Here lives a lasting memory of the dead.
sp.stage: Exeunt. A solemne marth. Manet Borgias
sp.l: Thus far my pioning policies run even,
And level with my aims: Iulia lives,
And in her hearse Timoclea my wife,
Deludes the credulous Dukes: poisoned last night
By Mulleasses, to make way for me,
To marry Iulia my brothers daughter,
For which the Cardinal of Aniou my kinsman
Solicits daily with his holiness,
For dispensation with our bloods alliance:
As for these weak men, whose pursuits in love,
Dies with my strong averring of her death,
I can command their lives: and then maintain
My actions with the sword: for which the Turke
By Mulleasses made unto my purpose,
Offers me forty thousand Ianisaries
To be my guard, against foreign outrages:
And more: he will make me king of Italy,
To give him but command upon the straights,
And land his force on this side Christendom
And I will do it: on my faith to God
And loyalty I owe unto the stars,
Should there depend all Europe and the states
Christened thereon: I would sink them all,
To gain those ends I have proposed my aims,
Religion (thou that ridest the backs of Slaves
Into weak minds insinuating fear
And superstitious cowardness) thou robbest
Man of his chief bliss by bewitching reason.
Nature at these my brows bend: thy mysteries
Wrought by thine own hands in our active brains,
Give us the use of good: thou art my God,
If what I have of thee, or wit or art,
Or Serpent sliding through the minds of men,
Cunning confusion of all obstacles,
Be they my children's lives, my dearest friends
May gain me what I wish, I stoop at thy renown
And think all is vacuum above a crown,
For they that have the sovereignty of things,
Do know no God at all, are none but Kings.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Eternal substitute to the first that moved
And gave the Chaos form. Thou at whose nod
Whole Nations stooped, and hold thee still a God:
Whose holy-customed-ceremonious rites,
Live unprophaned in our posterity:
Thou God of Mecha, mighty Mahomet,
Thus Mulleasses at thy memory
Descends: accept his prone humility,
Great Prophet: let thy influence be free
Unchecked by danger: mew not up my soul,
In the pent room of conscience:
Make me not moral Mahomet, cooped up
And fettered in the fools philosophy,
That points our actions unto honesty.
Give my plots fortune: let my hope but touch
The mark I aim at: then the gazing time
Shall in the present hide my former ill
Success like Lethe to the souls in bliss
Makes men forget things past and crowns our sins
With name of valour, be we impious.
A Scelus felix styles us virtuous.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: My honoured Lord:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: What devil interrupts in?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: My duty.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Your duty is too diligent that dares
Peer into my retreats: now should I kill thee.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: The Lord Protector Borgias my maister---

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Age and diseases breed consumptions
And rot him. What craves he?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: Your instant presence.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: I have instant business whose high import
Detains my speed: know you the matter?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: A tumult amongst the fearful multitude,
Caused by an ominous terror in the heavens,
Is as I guess the reason of your want.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: What heavens? what terror?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: The Sun on sudden feels a dark eclipse
And hides his silver face behind the moon,
As loath to see some prodigies appear.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Make that eclipse eternal Mahomet.
Rise, rise ye misty-footed Jades of night,
Draw your dark mistress with her sable veil,
Like a black Negro in an Ebony chair,
Athwart the worlds eye: from your foggy breaths
Hurl an Egyptian grossness through the air,
That none may see my plots: Hast any greater news?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: The days eyes out, a thousand little stars
Spread like so many torches, about the sky,
Make the world show like Churches hung with black,
And set with tapers at some funeral:
Amongst these stars directly from the East,
A fiery meteor points a burning rod
At Florence.

sp.speaker: Mulle.
sp.l: Perhaps it is thirsty for the blood of Princes,
Blaze out prodigious star, and let the fire
Dart soul amazing terror to all eyes:
Be like the Basilisk fatal to behold:
I will fat the slimy earth more than the plague,
And from her bosom send the blood of Kings
Styled into oily vapours and borne on high,
To expiate those flames that else would die.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: What answer shall I return unto my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mulle.
sp.l: That I will see him presently, be gone: Borgias,
Thou art no tutored Politician
To lay another in thy bosom.
Know a state-villain must be like the wind,
That flies unseen yet lifts an Ocean,
Into a mountains height. That on the sands
Whole Navies may be split in their descent.
I stand above thee, and as from a rock
Whose eminence outswells the raging flood,
See thy hopes shipwrecked: O credulity,
Securities blind nurse the dream of fools:
The drunkards Ape, that feeling for his way
Even when he thinks in his deluded sense,
To snatch at safety, falls without defence.
Twice hath the Nemean Lion breathed, forth fire,
And made the scalded Disaster pant with heat.
Twice the days planet through the burning signs
Hurried his fiery chariot since the time
I came to Florence in exchange for Iulia.
The son of Borgias here to learn the tongues,
The fashions and the arts of Christendom:
Now by my sly and affable intrusion
I am made intimate with Borgias:
He thinks my thought are Osiers to be wrought
In any form: the Dukes (that claimed
The love of Iulia) he hath deluded
By a feigned rumour of a sudden death:
Her he detains until he fits his time
By murder of the Dukes to be secure,
In his own power to back his marriage:
Timoclea his wife (the death of all his plots
If she survives) he now believes is dead
Poisoned by me: in lieu of which he grants
His daughter Amada to me for wife:
As if my hopes flew not as high as his:
Now to secure my flight and make my wings
Stronger than his that melted in the Sun,
His wife Timoclea lives within this tomb
Made seeming liveless by a sleepy juice
Infused in stead of poison in her cup:
Here I must wake her and in her stir up
Revenge against Borgias.
Image of death and daughter of the night,
Sister to Lethe all oppressing sleep,
Thou that amongst a hundred thousand dreams
Crowned with a wreath of mandrakes sittest as Queen,
To whom a million of care-clogged souls,
Lie quaffing juice of Poppy at thy feet,
Resign thy usurpation, and dislodge,
Hang on the eyes of sloth and make them sleep
Whose hearts are heavy, or whose sorrows weep,
Give way to motion: and thou whose blood
Stands in thy full veins like a charmed flood
Receive the air again: survive his hate
That on thy grave again climbs high to reach his fate.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Who speaks so loud?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: He that speaks life Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: You wake me.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Such power I challenge Lady in my voice,
To wake you from your grave.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: In your grave.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Ha, my grave!

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Be not amazed madam: you are safe.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Who speaks unto me? o forbear:
I am not for your presence: see my bed
Lies much unseemly: who attends me there?
What means this impudent intrusion?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Take time to your amazement: know where you are
It is Mulleasses speaks to you: him you once loved:
It is not now time to fear.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I know your face and yet I fear my being
Gives cause of fear.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Give yourself, to me and on those rites
Due to the sweets of love, here is no danger.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Accept me in your arms.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: See where you are, know you this place?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Some Church I think.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: And these the Trophies of your Ancestors.
This is the burial common to your blood.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: O free me from amazement, what strange accident
Brought me so near my death? I am now myself
And truly capable of a discourse.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Then know madam your life hath been pursued,
And myself bribed to be your poisoner,
But that my love turned death unto a sleep,
And brought you thus alive unto your grave:

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Say on my dearest Lord, who bribed thy love?
What barbarism, or what desert of mine
Moved this attempt against my life?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: My soul durst justify your innocence,
But that disease that bred in Paradise,
Swells like the Presters poison in our veins
(To which all men are heirs ambition)
Desire to be like God: it was that corruption
Gave me occasion thus to show my love
On your lives safety:

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My love and life are thine: speak openly,
What breast could be so cruelly ambitious?
Whose honour or whose fortunes could my life
Eclipse or darken?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.l: First madam you must swear,
By life, by love, and by that happiness
Your soul assures you in the faith you hold
With me, this night to prosecute revenge
On your lives enemy.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: By life, by love and by that happiness,
My soul assures me in the faith I hold,
By that which binds me more---by this
I swear this night to prosecute revenge
On my lives enemy.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Enough: thy resolution like a fire,
Makes my warm blood boyle: Borgias.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My husband.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Your husband: start not Lady,
It was he that by a promise of your daughter
The fairest Amada to me for wife
Made my tongue say, that I would poison you:
Silence dear Lady: choke all passion,
And feminine complaints in thoughts of vengeance.
Forget you are a woman: and be like your wrongs
Full swollen with death: let your inventive brains
Carry more fate in their conception,
Than Hecubas womb to Troy: my plots are yours,
Are you revengeful?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: As full as Jealousy: or the wife of Iason
Robbed by the fair Corinthian of her love.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Then thus we seal our resolution---
Thus I ascend, and from proud Fortunes wheel,
Pull my own fate: forgiveness Mahomet
My hopes make me profane; and my proud thoughts
Usurp above thy greatness; Apprehension?
Thou that givest food unto the soul of man,
The best companion to relieve the mind.
What sweet suggestions of my future bliss
Have I from thee? O I am transported
Beyond the power of reason! the present time
Craves a more sober temper. Madam this disguise
Must carry you unknown unto my chamber
Where we have much to do: release your thoughts,
Give freedom to those faculties of nature,
That made your sex first dare to reach at pleasure.
Be proud and lustful, let ambition sway
The power of action in you: murder and blood
Are the two pillars of a statesman's good.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: A Politician Proteus-like must alter
His face and habit, and like water seem
Of the same colour that the vessel is
That doth contain it, varying his form
With the Chameleon at each objects change,
Twice like a Serpent have I cast my skin,
Once when with mourning sighs I wept for Iulia,
And made the two Dukes weep for Iulia,
That coat is cast: now like an Amourist,
I come in loving terms to court my Iulia,
And seem a lover, but of all shapes
This sits me worst: whose constellation
Stamped in my rugged brow the signs of death,
Envy and ruin: strong Antipathies
Against love and pleasure: yet must my tongue
with passionate oaths and protestations,
With sighs, smooth glances, and officious terms,
Spread artificial mists before the eyes
Of credulous simplicity: he that will be high,
Must be a Parasite, to fawn and lie.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: How stand your thoughts affected to the marriage
I lately did acquaint you with, are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: I am: Rather to die than live to see that hour

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I would see Iulia, pray her company?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Your presence is most welcome:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: What business of import?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Nought for the instant but a wooing scene,
Prepare your wit my Lord to fight with words.
The Champions straight approach, but two to two.

div2.stage: Enter Iulia and Amada. Borgias courts Iulia, and Mulleasses Amada, glancing his eye on Iulia.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: My loved dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Beauteous Madam.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Fair as the morning.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Be as thy beauty seems, propitious, loving:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Attractive Sunshine: all affections moving.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: More than a subject, and more humbly bent.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How supple seems ambition? Uncle you are too low:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Divinest fair to whom all hearts should bow.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Fit attributes for heaven: my Lord, my feature
Is but earthmould, the weak frame of nature.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Yet graced with heavenly virtue, it seems divine

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I know your lights above me, yet let it shine
Like the days beauty on the lowly plains.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Subjects are no fit loves for Sovereigns.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: High comets from the earth draw up then nurture.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yet from the Sun true stars have all their lustre.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: True star on earth:

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: You flatter, pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Love Madam is importunate, you must hear:
Your niceness makes me be abrupt: I love
And must enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Hell to my love: Borgias I will prevent you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I must be plain: love you me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Aye by that power that made me.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Restore then that, that you have robbed me of,
My honour and my life: for I am dead,
So thought of in the world: give me what I am:
Return the title due unto my birth
Duchess of Florence, and thy Sovereign.
Make me as free as I was born, and give my love
The liberty of nature: then shall I believe
And think you love me.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I will restore your honours and your life,
I will return the duties of your birth:
Duchess of Florence and my Sovereign,
The Sovereign of my heart: and kneel to you,
And make my thoughts as humble as my knees:
See: I am not ambitious, it is not a crown
The gorgeous title of a Sovereign,
Makes me so evil in your thoughts: the poise of love
Whom some term light, and gives him wings
To soar aloft in me is but the same
And makes me stoop thus low to Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Uncle I am ashamed that any blood of mine
Should harbour such an incest: you have an easier way
To gain what you desire: make good the fame
The world is now possessed of: murther me,
Then are you heir to Florence: it is not half so ill,
As this incestuous mixture you so plead for,
Against nature and the law of heaven: but on,
Use your usurped power; be still a villain:
My life is the utmost, and you may command it,
But my bloods vessel given unto my soul,
As a pure mansion to inhabit in
Shall while I am and breath, be unprophaned.
I will be more chaste than Lucrece, die unstained.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: You are a woman Lady, and will change:
The Protector's at a nonsuit in his love,
How now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Thus crossed by superstitious obstinacy,
I will use the power I have, and make---How thrives your suit?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Unthrifty like yours: we are no Venus darlings,
No delight for women: she cannot love.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: She cannot love? your reason Lady
Is your blood holy? are you a sanctuary
That none may violate. What ease of conscience
Keeps you unprophaned? know that religion
Binds your obedience minion to my will.
Love him or I will hate thee.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: I tender up the duty of a child
And yield a fathers high prerogative
Over what I am: yet for that affection
That you would have me captive in his breast,
Know it is prisoner at so dear a rate,
As all my strength can no way ransom it.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I will use no rhetoric Lady to your ears:
But hear what I command, and do my will,
Or thou shalt hear what will displease thy will.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Be these the precepts Christians give their children?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: But Madam for your love.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: I would forsake a God.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: A more soft style be seems a subjects tongue,
I will be no higher than myself: and not command
Whats in my power. Will you resign your love?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye to that God that thou hast so profaned,
Detested Atheist.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Be religious Madam still and rail not,
Think of my honest suit: and think what power
This hand doth gripe: we are troublesome
And leave you to your thoughts: these fits must end,
Trees are as easy broke that will not bend.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p:
This is the hour I should meet my catamite Seignior Bordella: I cannot but laugh to see the slave make a lecherous progress to Lucifer. The moral will hold rarely: he shall have his brains fly about his ears in the hight of his venery: this instead of going to Tymoclea shall conduct him to the
bed of Borgias: amidst whose waking plots and state volutions, the amorous youth must needs be heartily welcome: for mine own part, my hand shall be clear from the blood of the goat: and yet I could account it happiness to be within ear shot of his departure, to hear how lamentably the coxcomb would sigh out Tymoclea: but the best is, neither Court nor country will much miss the fool: there are elder brothers enough to supply his room:
And see where the Cocoloch appears: he passeth as if he would steal to hell without company: whist Seignior.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Eunuchus?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: The same: now I see thou wilt stand to thy word.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Thy Lady shall see that in my deeds Eunuchus if all the sweet meats in Florence be provocative.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Aye Sir, but Ladies are of the nature of Idols and will be served on your knees.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: True, were I not a man of war whose valour and magnanimous courage is not to be dejected so long as his weapon holds.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Then I perceive you will shortly be at my Ladies mercy

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: If I should, doubt not her gracious hand in my erection: but gentle Eunucus, the key that opens to the Via lactea:

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Here Sir, and look your entrance be wary, soft and circumspect.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I had thought an entrance rough, manly and boisterous had been more pleasing to Ladies:

But see Eunuchus I shall be troubled I shall be tormented with this court owl if you assist me not: 'sfoot the flesh-fly hath espied me, she will never line sucking at me so long as I have any matter for her to work upon.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p:
Who, Madam Fulsome the Governess of the maids? she is a good creature and very musical: she sets more instruments a-work than a Fiddler: thou must needs love her if it were
but for her humility: she will bend herself to the meanest page of the Scullery: and she hates the pride of the flesh exceedingly, and is known to be a mortifier of carnality.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I verily believe it, for her very countenance and complexion shows she is able to allay any man's courage living with a breath.

div2.stage: Enter two Ladyes and Phego a Gentleman Vsher.

sp.speaker: Fulsom.
sp.p: Phego do you espy no motions behind the arras, no squalls, muffling, or pages standing sentinel? or because our head the Lady Iulia is dead, are all her servants that is her members in the same predicament?

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: Surely I see nobody stirring Lady: it is supper time and every man is providing for the belly.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: It will be shortly time for every woman to provide for the belly too, Phego a word with you.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: What is that Phego Eunuchus, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: How, know him, can I mistake him sir, that is never hoodwinked? he is an extreme enemy to Haberdashers: affecting no block, but that which nature bestowed on him: and of that he hath been so curious that it is not a hair amiss: he is sir the preface to your compoundress of man's flesh, and Ushers her to employment: and is a creature of singular patience; contenting himself with the Theory, when others are the Practic. In his pace he imitates Fencers, and stands much upon distance: He is partly an Astronomer too, being much given to observation of signs: for when the Sun is in Gemini the Dog star attends without doors: he is a great friend to Aries but naturally hates Pisces for it is a chill sign and cools his toes over-vehemently: in brief sir he is a Gentleman Vsher.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p:
Sure Phego that should be seignior Bordello: I pray you entreat his approach: of all our Courtiers I love men of his country and breeding, they are the lovingest, best spoken, well graced
creatures in these parts extant: I think it be given to those that be born under your northern clime, to thaw and melt away at the Sun-shine of beauty: you shall read in very late stories that many of them have lost their best members in the service of Ladies and distressed waiting Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I should account it none of my nearest mishaps, being interdicted so worthy a presence by more than urgent affairs. Sweet Sir bear my excuse with all respective desire of pardon.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Whether Seignior Bordello in such post-haste: you forget your old friends: when you came first to Court, you and I were more inward man.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Being upon my departure Lady, I am enforced to see to the conveying of my goods, and the trussing away of my baggage.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: And that word baggage (I will be sworn) had been an apt phrase for his bringing in, but you purpose not I hope seignior to depart Florence altogether.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: O no: his flight Lady is like the Ravens, that having spied a fat carcass, roams about to clamour of her fellows to the prey.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: But seignior, have you so fully furnished your discourse with observation, as with so 'slight a view of our Gentlewomen to make a departure? indeed seignior the Ladies of your country will exact some observative relate of your travels upon your return.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: For our Ladies Madam they are few or none, our country men are not so addicted to titles of honour: they use knighthood as rich Jewellers desire gems rather for traffic than ornament.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: Is there any commodity to be had in the purchase sir?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Great Commodity, and that is the reason so many merchants and yeomen sons hunt after it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Belike this is one of your observations: pray sir be more open: I see you have profited much since your coming.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: For the bettering of mine inward parts, some few notions I have committed to memory.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Impart them Seignior: it may be I shall add to your store: these Ladies will not discover us for intelligencers: they are naturally given to the concealment of private actions.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Since my coming to Florence I have seen ignorance in the shape of a Citizen muffled in the scarlet of magistracy that could not write his own name. Generally I have noted through the whole Country great enmity between wit and cloaks lined through with velvet: and yet beggars and gallants agree together very familiarly. There is no thriving but by impudence and panderism: he that is furnished with one of these two qualities shall beg more of a foolish Lord at a marrowbone breakfast, than all the Poets in the whole town shall rime out of him in an age:

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: But these are but petty observations: I have seen since my coming to Florence the son of a Peddler mounted on a foot cloth: a fellow created a Lord for the smoothness of his chin: and which is more; I have seen a cap most miraculously turned into a beaver hat without either trimming or dressing.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: That is strange indeed: Seignior and Eunuchus, we are to press you to a further courtesy in meeting us in the lobby some two hours hence at a posset.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: You shall find us as forward in as hot a service in the Lobby or elsewhere at your Ladyships appoint, but--

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: We must have no denial.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Canst not say the Court-grace? promise man promise.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Your Ladyship shall find us ready to put in---our spoons.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Till then adieu Seignior and Eunuchus. Phego forward.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: So long as my ham-strings hold.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: You see Eunuchus, familiarity and courtesy hath enwrapped me in the knowledge of these meanest vassals of honour: but henceforth my countenance shall be estranged, and I will bury my acquaintance in silence.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p:
I think the Cuckoo fore-sings his own dirge: Seignior, you shall need no further prescriptions: in the career of your delight, vouchsafe a thought of Eunchus, you conceive me
Sir, manifest my service to Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: I were inhumane if I should forget you the latest minute of my life: pray heavens my Page Pantofle have procured in my absence the embroidered shirt I gave directions for upon both our wardrobes: that care once over, I shall never henceforth taste of lousy misfortune.
sp.l: Venus supplying what Bordello most lacks,
Courtiers and Porters live by able backs.

div2.stage: Scena. 4. Enter 4. Tapers borne by 2. Pages, Borgias, Venice, Florence, Mulleasses, Prusias, Philenzo.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Thus our presumption hath prolonged your stay
At a cheap banquet: did not the rites of love
Exact your presence as a debt to Iulia,
Our boldness might have wanted an excuse
Thus to detain you.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: You are too full of ceremony my Lord,
Knowing your welcome prodigal, and full of state,
And such as fits our mournful accidents.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: The better part of love due to the living,
Appears in friends even when their friends are dead.
And think my Lord Protector that our love,
For which we came in arms against your walls,
Would not be wanting in one ceremony
Due unto Iulia at her obsequy.
Is Prusias returned from our Camp?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Aye my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Doth our Lieutenant keep a careful watch
Are Sentinels set out?

sp.speaker: Prus.
sp.l: They are if it like your grace.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Where is Philenzo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Are all in safety at our Camp?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Safe and in quiet.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: The night is old,
And drowsy sleep hangs heavy on our eyes:
Conduct us to our rest.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Never till now was Borgias fully blessed:
To lodge two mighty Princes in one night
Under his roof: where my sons son may say,
Here mighty Uenice and Ferrara lay.
My Lord these Tapers lead you to your chamber,
These great Ferrara unto yours.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Rest to you all.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Good night and sleep unto your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Sweet quiet be a guard unto you both,
So may you sleep for ever. Eunuchus:
Remove with our attendance from our ears.
Now my hearts treasurer: what now remains?
My resolution holds to murder them,
And with that force the town may now afford,
Practise some sudden stratagem on their powers.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: That were too violent: things done for state,
Must carry form, and with an outward gloss,
Varnish and cover what would else seem gross,
Should they be murdered in their beds, or die,
Having your promise for their guard: the offence
Could have no safety but in violence.
No let them sleep secure, and this nights safety
Will make them fearless, easy to be trapped
In a more cunning net.
Tomorrow at a banquet they shall drink
A drug, whose working in their breast shall sleep
Twice fifteen days, until their absence hence
May give you colour from suspicion.
But then dissolving like a fire that is hid,
Spreading a burning poison through the blood,
It scalds the heart, and through the body runs:
Turns to a hot quotidian and, doth leese
Although of poison in a mad disease:
So dying, no impute can touch your name:
Things are undone that are unspeaks by fame.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: My fortunes on thy council noble Turke.
We will clime together: my daughters heady will
Shall stoop unto thy pleasure: as for Iulias love
She must or yield or die: he that is wise,
Will tread on any that may make him rise.

div2.stage: Actus 3 Scene 1 Enter Timoclea like a Ghost.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Blush not thou chaste and modest Queen of night,
Nor hide thy silver crescent in a cloud,
To see me thus Rhamnusia like attired:
Stare on ye Argues eyed heavens and sea woman
More full of vengeance, than your jealous Queen.
Medusa sometime the love of Neptune,
(But after for thy lust transformed a monster)
Lend me those serpents that about thy head
Curl up like Elf-knots, at whose horrid sight
The Sun may vanish or stand still affright.
Or you you Furies ministers of fear,
(That at Astreas feet lie bound in snakes
Attending her just sentence to begin
Terror of conscience in the breast of sin)
This night be powerful in me and inspire
My face with fear, my heart with rack-swollen ire.
Venice, Venice, great Venice:

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: Who speaks to Venice?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Iulia thy love.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Delusive voice, why dost renew my grief
By naming Iulia?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Didst thou love Iulia?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Thou wrongest me to make question of my love.
Whatsoever thou art.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Then see thy Iulia and revenge her wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Dissolve ye glassy pearls and melt in drops,
Or with the tear-spent mother Niobe
Turn into stones: shall I believe my thoughts,
And credit what thy shape presents to me?
Thou art the Ghost of murdered Iulia.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Immortal essence Virgin-element
So may I term thy airy substance freed
From the gross mixture of our earthly load:
O I am thronged with passions and each craving vent
None can have passage till some tears be spent,
Fall fall ye silver pearls, and of the earth
Purchase a soft relenting at my griefs.
Shower down like rainy drops, and pearce the stones
Make them receive my sorrows, or from mine eyes
Run like to crystal rivers through the world,
Slide over the flowery meadows that the Nymphs
Dancing in fairy rings upon the grass,
May leave their sport, and weep to see you pass,
Where by the doleful murmur as you go,
The hills may hear you mourn and sound my woe,
Pardon: if I be tedious virgin spirit,
Or if my grief be too effeminate:
Thy habit is an Index to revenge,
Which thy wrongs seem to plead for of my love,
Speak them, or deal them through the yielding air
Into my ears, and they shall be to me
Like the stern drum, or music of the war
Unto the coward, or the fainting soldier.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Venice I was murdered.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Murder is open mouthed, and as the Sea
Whose covetous waves imprisoned by thy land,
Bellow for grief and roar upon the sand.
So from the earth it cries, and like a child
Wronged by his careless nurse will not be stilled:
Are ye then deaf yea gods, ye cannot hear it?
Or is just Libra fallen out of your Spheres,
That wronged States must to the earth appeal
For justice and revenge. Then it is not profane
To usurp your functions: my hand shall be as just
As my soul loving: and they both shall leave
A story to the world of my revenge.
Nor in succeeding times shall be forgot.
Venice revenged those wrongs the heavens would not.
I interrupt what that wouldst say, and seem
To crown all vengeance in a passion.
Speak but his name.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My uncle Borgias.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.l: Enough.
O that the genius that attends on man,
Should be a doubtful Oracle to the soul
And whispering to our intellect what fate
Hangs like a falling tower upon his state,
Yet be no more of force to length our joy,
Then were Cassandras prophecies to Troy.
Disloyal treacherous villain Borgias,
Some Hydras poison, or the blood of Nessus
Cleave to thy flesh:
O my blood swells beyond my power: my voice
Louder than his that thunders through the clouds,
Shall speak this monstrous murder to the world,
I will be thy Orator wronged spirit and plead
Blood and revenge for thee though thou beest dead.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Ven:
sp.l: What wouldst thou more?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Hear and be advised:
Tomorrow when the Senate sits be there,
And in the ears of the whole state proclaim,
And justify my words against Borgias:
In this alone I will great Uenice prove,
Do it as ever thou didst Iulia love.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Whilst I borne upon air attend my bliss.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Peace to thy soul: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Remember Iulia.
Yet prosper and go on, for Iulias ghost
My false shape takes: the abused Duke's afire,
Through Borgias blood I will run to my desire.
Whom have we Here?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Priapus thou woman's God assist me with a Jovial ability: this night I may beget a Hercules: Fortune I must confess thou hast turned up thy muffler: and cast a gracious aspect on Bordello: for I am not only in the state of clean linen; but also thou hast made me gracious in the eye of Seignior Diaspermaton my Apothecary, who hath furnished me with this receipt: Here is a compound of Cantharides Diositerion, marrow of an Ox, hairs of a Lion, stones of a Goat, Cock-sparrows brains, and such like this after an hours receipt, hath a fourfold operation: and lest I should be like a Peacock all tail and no heart, Here is a distillation of ten pound a pint, that comforts the inward, fires the brains, cheers up the spirit, and makes a man lay about him like a dutchman. Let me see, it is more than time that I commit this divine pill to his hopeful working: lest my staff be out of the rest when my adversary is in the career. So Cupids fair mother be thy midwife: out and alas I am mare rid, what Somners Ghost or limb of Lucifer, puts poor Bordello in mind of penance before he hath trespassed?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I am espied: his fear doth apprehend me for a ghost,
And I must feed it.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Se, it makes toward me: infortunate Bordello that the devil should be an enemy to lechery.

div2.stage: Scaena. 2. Enter Madame Fulsome, Eunuchus and Phego.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Come let us set to our business, Phego,
Lend us your wind to cool this posset.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: It is not the first time I have been constrained to puff and blow in your Ladyships service.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: It hath oft come in my mind to know the derivation and denomination of this word posset?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: I take it that it comes of the Latin word posse to make a man able: and that is the reason ever after eating them, men desire to make experience of their forces.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: I rather conceive it comes of the word pono of putting together, for that your possets are the usual means of congregating, putting and combining your Court creatures together.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: And that may well be: for I remember that reverent pedagogue William Lilly, brings in gigno, pono, cano, one in the neck of another, gigno to beget, pono to put in, and cano to sing.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: That Lilly was a beastly knave to put pono behind gigno there is no music in it: but all this time we miss not Seignior Bordello, it hath not be his custom to be absent where his chops might have had employment.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: You speak of the days of hunger, when the slave was a stranger in the land of Hauilab: but the word is retrograde: the last age is a golden age with him.

sp.speaker: Fuls.
sp.p: See where the son of Saturne appears.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: 'sfoot I thought the Dog-fish had been baiting Cerberus ere this time.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Ladies did you not see a spirit pass this way?

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.p: Thou seest we are feeding the flesh man, what dost thou talk of the spirit?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Without jest a mere Ghost, standing bolt upright at Timocleas chamber, so nigh Court Incubus on my life.

sp.speaker: Fuls.
sp.p: Were you not much terrified Seignior with the apparition?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: How: terrified? I no sooner beheld it, but drawing my better parts together
Help, help!

div2.stage: All run out, Timoclea followes the Eunuch out.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Fear and suspicion, two night-waking charms,
Banish all sleep, suggesting in my thoughts,
Falsehood and treason: I am slow and dull,
Descending like the earth: yet I know not what
Pricks like the thorne of Philomel at my breast:
And tells me there is danger in my rest.
Sometime I think of Iulia: and that thought
Presents her loves in a living shape.
When not remembering death, I ope my arms,
To tie a Gordian knot about her waste
And bid her welcome: but that empty clasp,
Deluding my false hopes with nought but air,
Makes my blood angry, and doth turn my passion
To seek a subject fit for my revenge:
And then I ever think of Borgias,
As if my love were wronged by Borgias.
What means these sudden tumults in mine ears?
Save me eternal guard of innocence:
Treason, treason, villain thou shalt buy my blood.

div2.stage: Eunuchus rusheth in: he kils him: Enter Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: O spare me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Distraction of my brain, what shape art thou?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Iulias

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Iulia: ha: stay it is gone: did I see?
Or did my fear and fancy frame this form?
Villain thou art some instrument of falsehood
Confess thy treason.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: You are secure: that shape that named your love
Pursued me through the court, till for my rescue
Fear made me use this violence at your chamber.
O I am slain, and die a causeless death,
I never lived false to thee: all thou hast gained
Is that my soul dies clear and leaves thine stained.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: To do thee good my soul shall say as much
And witness it before the Judge of souls,
When at the general Bar we meet together.
But I must use thy shape: this night I will walk
Hid in thy habit from discerning eyes:
I will pry about the Court, perhaps I may
Once more see Iulias ghost, and learn her wrongs,
By them to aim a right in my revenge.
My hand first dies the scene: and it shall fill
The stage with vengeance: Nemesis shall wade
Up to the chin and bath herself in blood,
The dangling snakes that hang about her neck
Shall suck like Lethe of the purple gore
Shed for my Iulias death.
I will feast the ravenous people of the air,
And fill the hungry wolves with slaughtered men.
The streets of Florence like the streets of Rome
(When death and Sylla ranged) shall run with blood.
Their swelling channels with a scarlet tide
Shall wash the stores, and for my Iulias death
The angry gods of wrath shall smile as pleased
To se me so revenged: Eunuchu, thy death
Is but a prologue to induce a plot,
Mayst thou be blessed, thou art not worth my hate
I must reach higher, and on thy disguise,
Lay but the ground-work for revenge to rise.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Be pleased ye powers of might, and bout me skip
Your antic measures: like to cole black moors,
Dancing their high Lauoltos to the Sun
Circle me round: and in the midst I will stand,
And crack my sides with laughter at your sports.
O my hopes fatten me: nor shall time grow old,
Or weary with attending my success.
One night shall crown me happy: Borgias wife
Appears unto the Dukes for Iulias ghost,
To breed suspicion in them of her murder,
So that if Borgias chance survive this night
(As he must die if all my plots hits right)
The Dukes tomorrow when the Senate sits
May prove what I will affirm against his life.
Nor to redeem his safety shall he bring
The Lady to disprove what we aver.
Here will I cease, and in some strange disguise
Keep till my growing faction be of force
To second my ambition for the crown.
If I plot well fair Amada must die,
And by her mothers hand: she must not live
To speak her fathers wrongs. Timoclea
Thou, thou art next: I took thee from thy grave
Not for the love I bore Timoclea,
But to suck from thy use the sweets of love
I bore to Iulia: it was love and state.
Gave thee this time of life to strength my fate:
But blab not: silence tongue: she comes.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My Lord, what, drowned in contemplation?
Mulleasses: love.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Heavenly creation, beauties abstract, natures wonder.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: What means my Lord? awake, Timoclea speaks.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: I must enjoy thee Amada: strong force of passion.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Ha: Amada: dearest Lord: your sense
And know me.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Ha Timoclea: thy love and pardon, I was over-borne,
And carried from myself with idle thoughts
Of what sad melancholy suggested in me:
What comfort bringest thou? hath thy dead shape
Been powerful unto fear? stood they amazed?
Their eyes like fired stars set on thy face:
Their speech abrupt and short: their hair upright?
Stiff like the quills of Porcupines? art blessed?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I am: if what you speak may make me blessed.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: It makes us happy: gives our hope true life.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Neither my life nor hope to be so blessed
Makes me so happy as thy love dear Turke.
Were I a Venus thou shouldest be my Mars,
And I would court thee even in Phebus sight,
Although it moved an envy in the gods.
Be Jovial: and like Salmecis, thy love
Shall cling about thy neck.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: I am not sportful:

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I will dance before thee like a fairy Nymph,
And with my pleasing motions make thee sport:
I will court thee naked, as did the Queen of thoughts
Her sullen boy, and all to make thee sport.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: You are not pleasing.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Not pleasing gentle Turke?
Time hath not set the characters of age
On my smooth brow: my pulses beat as high,
As when my first youth lifted up my blood,
I buy no beauty: nor hath nature been
A niggard in my face: I am yet young
Fresh and delightsome, as the checkered spring,
The Lilly and the Rose grow in my cheeks,
And make a bed for love to rest him on.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: But I am restless.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Rest thee on my breast.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: No I must pilgrim to a love divine.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Love me and unto love I will build a shrine
And on an Altar offer to our loves,
The thighs of Sparrows and of Turtle Doves.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: You are importunate.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Yield then and I have done.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: No more:
Fair Amada's the saint that I adore.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Amada: minion is it you?
Makes me thus sue unheard? my daughter Amada
Have I in my bosom nursed a snake:
No fierce-streamed torrent, nor no storm at Sea,
No stepdame is halt so raging: my blood was not so strong,
When thou wert got: now it is like the Sea,
My soul a Bark that runs with wind and tide
And cannot stop: the Anchor of my thoughts
(Reason) is lost, and like the vine-gods priests
Running down Nila or from Pindus top,
I am unstaid and doubtful in my course.
O the strong power of sense: I must do that
Which all succeeding times to come shall speak
Yet not believe; all say it was done, yet none
Say it was well done. Love is a God,
Strong, free, unbounded, and as some define,
Fears nothing, pitieth none: such love is mine.

div2.stage: Actus 4. Scena 1. Enter Iulia and Amada.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: O had our souls no deeper sense than flesh,
Were they like waxen pictures formable:
Obsequiously to take impression
From every rude hand, and be like this will,
That wills us unto some deformity,
I should not Amada complain of wrong
But make religion of my forced restraint:
I then should sleep and pray: and on my beads
Number devotion: my environed spirit
Should not thus swell beyond my present freedom:
Whisper my wrongs and prompt my weaker powers
To prone impatience

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Madam I am yours.
Let not the name of daughter unto him
That hath confined your hope, be prejudice
To those affections I bear your state:
I will prove against reason and received truth,
Like breeds not like, in breeding everything:
Clear streams may flow even from a troubled spring.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: I am no infidel to thy position,
Sad thoughts oppress me: may I have no music?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Some say that when the Thracian entered hell,
The tortured souls enchanted with his tunes,
Felt not their torments: Syciphus sate down,
Ixions wheel stood still: the thirsty son of Jove,
Forgot to drink, and all the rest did stand
Catching the air from his delicious hand:
I would I might partake their happiness.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Madam you shall: give your ears a while,
And you shall hear such music as would make
The greedy wolf forsake the tender lamb,
And listen to it: such as the son of Neptune
Played to the Dolphins: when they in a ring
Danced their crooked measures but to hear him sing.
Madam how fare you now?

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Even as the labouring day man after sleep.
Refreshed and cherished: ha but Amada.

sp.speaker: Amad.
sp.l: Some better Genius assist my fear.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: What would it Amada, it beckons to thee?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: My mothers troubled spirit: O defend me heavens.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Away: Amada.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: It commands my absence.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: O for heavens sake stay.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Something it would unfold to thee: I go:

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Contain thy fear, I live.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Such terror lives not in a living eye,
Death is not sharper than those pointed beams
That pierce unto my heart.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Would they were poniards digging at thy breast.
Keep in thy short-drawn accents: let not the air
Carry the softest clamour to the ear
Of waking Jealousy: if it do---
How Lust and Nature do divide my soul?
The one doth plead prescription in my blood,
And sues as plaintive with such clamorous spells,
As might conjure the violent rape of Lust
To modest continence: O but it is a vice
Sooner condemned than banished: easily spoke against
But yet it will fawn smoothly on our flesh,
As Circe on the Grecian travellers,
When she detained them in the shape of beasts.
Amada knowest thou my face?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: I knew that outward Character of her
That sometimes I called mother.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Dost think I have no life?
Seest not my blood in a continual pulse
Beat through the azure conduits of my flesh?
Feel how I burn: what starest thou on me?
Am I transparent? canst see from my heart
Death in the shape of jealousy: stand
Like a chief organ guiding all my frame,
Unto some tragic action?

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: O give my sense some freedom
From fear and terror, that I may distinguish
Betwixt the credulous rumour of your death,
And what I see.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I live, the time befits not inquisition
Of tedious circumstance: Amada I live:
But thou must die, and by thy mothers hand.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: O be not a Medea.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why like Creusa hast thou stolen my Iason?
My Mulleasses he dotes upon thee:
I am debarred his breast,
Robbed of his love by thy alluring looks.
Sad discontent wound in his folded arms,
Sighs nought but Amada: but by my better hopes
My blood shall like Medusas first turn to serpents
And taint thy flesh, ere it shall loose that fire
Which makes it boyle and burn in his desire.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Deform my beauty fill my face with scars,
Make me more loathsome than a dead man's scull:
Wash me with spiders blood, that I may swell,
And be more ugly than a Gorgons head,
That he may fear to see me: only let me live,
And spare me that that only you did give.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My pleasure gave thee life, and it resumes
That life again, because it kills my pleasure:
Thou art like an Ivy nourished at the root
Of some proud oak: that not content to creep
And feed upon the sap, but stretching up,
Proudly presumest to over look the top:
So that the verdure of the ambitious imp,
Detains all admiration: the Oak wants grace,
Only because the Ivy is in place.
But I will displant thee for no weed shall grow
So near the root from whence my sap doth flow.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: Cruel unnatural: heaven my hopes in thee
If virgin pureness please, accept of me.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: What, do you Christians sacrifice with flesh?
Or like the Laodiceans unto Pallas, offer
The blood of virgins? O inhumane deed,
Ungentle monster, beauteous Amada!

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: It was her beauty that I offered up
Unto thy love my dearest Mulleasses.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Worse than a Camel in her time of lust,
Cruel unto thy child: loose thy snaky arms
O thou hast done

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: As Lucius Catalline
Romes terror did for Orestalla, killed
My child: no more: for Mulleasses love,
I would outgo examples, and exceed
As in desire, all others so indeed.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: And yet I love thy cruelty: for this night thou must
Discard the timorous pity of thy Sex:
Be a Semiramis: let thy husbands death
Give thy hopes life: feed, feed upon his blood,
And let thy veins swell: now he prepares to bed
Be thine own ghost: and like the apparition
Of his believed-dead wife call for revenge:
Incite his timorous conscience to despair,
Speak of damnation: let one word contain
A hell of torments. But time slides.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I run.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Much ere the morning riseth must be done,
I will bear this body hence: ha ha ha,
O now methinks I gin out-reach myself,
Now like some huge Colossus cold I strut,
And stride that Oak of Mahomet: that bears up
The ponderous centre: whose divided horns
Measuring the passing of a thousand years,
Touch at both Poles, and toss the massy ball:
Makes mountains nod and curled Cedars reel
On Syrian Lybanus. But soft methinks I hear
Some mutinous and distracted tumult.

div2.stage: Enter Borgias and Timoclea after him.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Guard me ye just and intellectual powers
Thou triple and eternal essence.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Borgias.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: What dreadful summons calls on Borgias?
What art thou?

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Timoclea thy poisoned wife.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: What wouldst thou, Ha.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Revenge and horror.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Terror to my soul: forbear those looks.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Despair and vengeance.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Mayst thou be peaceful, in my prayers I wish it,
Let them expiate my sin: if thou beest a spirit
Blessed and celestial: change that face of fear,
Or leave the infectious grossness of our air,
And like an Angel dance about the Spheres,
Play with the Moon and make the Sun thy glass,
To see thy beauty as thy beauty pass.
Or if thou beest---

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: A messenger of death.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Then like a Fury post to Tartarus,
Fetch up the snaky curled Eumenides:
From Orcus bottom where revengeful cares
Grief, pale diseases, sad and crooked age
Are ever resident: let them and their effects
Let fierce Erennis with her brazen feet,
Seize me at once, and strike me in my fall,
Lower than him that durst ascend the Sun.
Only be thou appeased.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Not till I meet thee in the shades of death.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Which thou deniest me: for thy fears keep in
My trembling soul: it dares not leave my breast,
Mount to the flaming girdle of the world,
And fetch me lightnings, I will swallow it.
